1.name: The Y2K Convergence
1.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “We thought the clocks would fail. Instead, the walls between worlds did.”
    – Dr. Helene Asakura, SRD Founding Chair

The Y2K Convergence Event—commonly referred to as simply “The Convergence”—was the cataclysmic moment on January 1st, 2000 when a cascade failure in a particle accelerator in Geneva, triggered by an anticipated Y2K software fault, caused a spatial resonance breach that merged Earth’s dimension with several others. The result was a fractured, reformed reality where cities, cultures, species, and technologies from wildly different universes were suddenly stitched into the framework of baseline Earth.

It was not the end of the world.
But it was the end of the world as we knew it.
🧨 What Happened

Rather than mere banking glitches or power outages, the Y2K bug in question corrupted the synchronization algorithms of the DAX-12 Particle Entanglement Array, a top-secret prototype accelerator. At the stroke of midnight, its containment field buckled, tearing open a dimensional convergence point—a space-time rupture of unprecedented scale.

In under thirty seconds:

    Reality destabilized across multiple key pressure points on Earth

    Entire cities (like Night City, Musutafu, and Luna Station Aegis) folded into Earth’s geography

    Fragments of infrastructure and ecosystems from alternate timelines, universes, and mythic constructs emerged in chaotic overlays

    Magic systems, metagenetics (e.g., Quirks), cybernetic frameworks, and alien biology all began coexisting in violent proximity

This was the First Convergence Pulse, and it altered the course of history in an instant.
🌍 Global Impact (2000–2010)

The first decade after the Event was defined by chaos and collapse:

    Governments fell, unable to respond to the sheer scale of existential rewriting

    Technologies collided—smartphones stopped working in zones where ambient mana overloaded circuits

    Mass casualties occurred in merged zones: people fused with structures, fell through spatial rifts, or couldn’t metabolize new air blends

    Civil wars and power vacuums emerged as new arrivals brought alien factions, hero academies, warlords, or even living myth

    Species from other universes, both sapient and wild, found themselves stranded on Earth or forcibly transported into urban zones

Religious panic, political radicalization, and infrastructure collapse marked the early years. Entire cities were lost or reshaped beyond recognition.
🛠️ Stabilization Era (2011–Present)

By 2011, stabilization efforts were spearheaded by emerging coalitions:

    The formation of the High Convergence Council, a unified government composed of major universe representatives

    The foundation of the SRD (Spatial Realignment Division) to monitor and contain dimensional instability

    Establishment of Starfleet oversight enclaves, UA Outreach programs, corporate-zone treaties, and Arcane Accords to regulate magic and tech interaction

    New cities and nations formed, including the Night City–LA Hybrid, UA Island, and the Starfleet Colonial Districts

Though Earth never returned to what it was, a new geopolitical equilibrium eventually formed, balancing the influx of people, technology, and arcana.
🔬 The Science Behind It (What We Think)

While full understanding is elusive, it’s generally agreed that the Y2K Event triggered:

    A quantum-causal cascade failure in the fabric of local space

    A resonance surge that targeted “story-rich” nodes across multiple dimensions

    An involuntary anchoring of alternate realities to Earth’s spacetime lattice

    Temporal bleed and identity resonance, resulting in paradoxical backhistories and fictional memory conflicts (now suppressed by decree)

The Event was not a single rupture—but a perpetual system instability that now defines Earth’s position in a multiversal web.
🔁 Residual Effects

    Dimensional Drift: People, creatures, or fragments from other worlds still occasionally “fall through” into Earth, often requiring SRD intervention

    Reality Fatigue: A psychological condition caused by prolonged exposure to unstable zones or timeline fragmentation

    Magitek and Technomancy: Hybrid fields that formed in areas where arcana and technology could not disentangle

    Species Flux: Some lifeforms mutate over time, adapting to merged conditions unpredictably

    Temporal Echoes: Echoes of lost or overwritten timelines surfacing as ghosts, glitches, or entire “phantom towns”

⚖️ Political & Cultural Fallout

    Earth is no longer just Earth: It is now a multi-origin convergence world, and governance reflects that

    Entire political bodies like the Federation of Colonized Sectors, UA Outreach Initiative, and Netwatch Compact trace their existence to Y2K

    Religion, philosophy, and identity have shifted worldwide, with many embracing new pantheons, magical traditions, or posthuman ideologies

    The Custodian Chair, the permanent emergency post within the Convergence Council, was created in anticipation of future instability

🧠 Public Perception

    Older generations remember it as a disaster, an apocalypse in everything but name

    Younger citizens see the Convergence as normal—dangerous, yes, but rich with opportunity

    Conspiracy theorists insist the Event was triggered intentionally by Starfleet, the Accord, or an alien AI

    Religious movements reframe the Event as divine intervention or punishment

    Most people?
    Just want to live their lives in a world where cities float, magic is real, and the sky might change color at any time

🏁 Final Notes

The Y2K Convergence Event was not a glitch.
It was a rebirth—one soaked in blood, confusion, and fire.

And while Earth survived,
it did not survive unchanged.

2.name: Earth
2.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “It’s still called Earth. But it sure as hell isn’t your Earth anymore.”

Earth, as it exists in 2025, is a fusion world—a patchwork of timelines, realities, and alien infrastructures caused by the Y2K Convergence Event. When a particle accelerator overloaded at midnight, January 1st, 2000, it didn't erase data. It ripped through spacetime, merging entire universes onto baseline Earth.

The first decade was chaos: alien skies, impossible architecture, governments crumbling under refugee influxes from other worlds. But from the wreckage rose a kind of order—The High Convergence Council—formed from the largest and most powerful universes involved. Earth now functions as a shared planet, managed by uneasy allies and stitched together through brute necessity.
🧭 Geography & Topography

Post-Convergence Earth is no longer geographically consistent with pre-2000 maps. Entire cities, islands, and landmasses appeared overnight:

    UA Island (Pacific Ocean): A full slab of My Hero Academia’s world, anchored just off Japan.

    Night City–LA Hybrid (California): Corporate-fueled cyberpunk sprawl from Cyberpunk 2077’s timeline fused with old Los Angeles.

    Starfleet Colonial Districts (Europe & orbit): Federation infrastructure including a partial starbase and terraforming platforms integrated with Swiss territory.

    Magitek Zones and Arcane Pockets: Regions infused with magically adapted ecosystems from merged high fantasy realms.

    Augmentation Arks: Floating and subterranean structures linked to megacorp-controlled domains from other realities.

Climate is stable—but warped. Some merged zones brought ecosystem shifts, alien flora/fauna, or territorial anomalies, but none violate basic physical laws. Magic and tech are real, but bound by their originating rules.
🚨 Current State (2025)

Earth has stabilized under inter-faction governance, though tension remains high. Cities thrive, but trust is low. Cultures coexist with caution. Everyone is still figuring out what counts as normal.

    Population: Estimated 14.7 billion (includes merged populations)

    Dominant Powers:

        Starfleet Oversight Corps (tech regulation, diplomacy)

        Netwatch Compact (cybersecurity and AI law)

        UA Outreach Initiative (quirk control and training)

        Corporate Blocs (economic power from cyberpunk megacorps)

        Baseline Earth Delegation (limited political influence)

    Common Threats: Black market tech, quirk accidents, AI insurgencies, magic misuse, dimensional instability

🔄 The Y2K Convergence Event
Year: 2000
Catalyst: A failed Y2K patch on a subterranean particle accelerator caused quantum bleed, folding multiple universes into Earth’s spatial footprint.
Timeline of Events:

    2000–2005: Immediate impact, mass infrastructure collapse, refugee crisis, anomalous disasters

    2006–2010: Territory stabilization, formation of High Convergence Council, and rebuilding efforts

    2011–Present: Integration phase; mixed-universe diplomacy, education systems, and enforcement agencies established

Random arrivals of individuals and small-scale structures still occur, known as Blink Events. Not as frequent as during the Chaos Decade, but still disruptive.
🏛️ The High Convergence Council

The High Convergence Council (HCC) is Earth’s only recognized global authority. It's not a government—it’s a compromise. Twelve permanent seats, filled by the largest universe-states, handle planetary-scale decisions: law enforcement, technology regulation, arrival management, and crisis containment.
🌐 Permanent Seats:

    Starfleet Oversight Corps – Science diplomacy and technology ethics

    Netwatch Compact – Digital security, AI law enforcement

    UA Outreach Initiative – Quirk integration, superhuman law

    Baseline Earth Delegation – Earth-native governments, mostly symbolic

    Corporate Bloc Representative – Rotates among megacorp alliances

    Federation of Colonized Sectors – Starfleet-aligned colony interests

    Arcane Accord – Coalition of magic-based factions

    AugNet Syndicate – Cyber-augmented technocratic alliance

    Driftborn Assembly – Stateless populations and micro-nations

    Orbital Belt Union – Off-world habitats, exo-Earth mining interests

    Interlink Embassy – Handles multi-universe trade and transit disputes

    Custodian Chair – Neutral arbitrator and tie-breaker, elected every five years

🛡️ Powers:

    Enforces Convergence Law

    Oversees SRD, Netwatch, and allied enforcement units

    Sanctions trade, tech transfer, and weaponized innovation

    Approves or denies entry petitions from newly arrived microfactions

    Maintains New Geneva Accords, the central legal framework of the new world

No one likes the Council. Everyone needs it. That’s what keeps it standing.
🧬 Merged Cultures & Society
🏙️ Urban Centers

    New Geneva: Capital of Council activity. Mix of Federation design, UN remnants, and high-tech bureaucracy.

    Neo Angeles: Corporate stronghold where chrome is currency. Blends Cyberpunk tech, Los Angeles sprawl, and mercenary rule.

    Tharsis Enclave: Federation-aligned city built from a fragment of a Martian base. Offers orbital ferry access.

    UA Pacific: Superpowered education hub run by My Hero Academia faculty and staff. Focus on quirk integration.

    Fluxhaven: A magically adapted free city. Magitek blended with modern infrastructure.

🔩 Society & Economy

    Trade routes run between universes.

    Currency depends on region: Council Credit, Universal Crypto, barter, or faction-backed bonds.

    Workforce includes humans, aliens, genetically enhanced, cybernetically modified, and spell-wielding citizens.

    Education, policing, and healthcare vary drastically depending on dominant universe influence in each region.

🛡️ Security & Enforcement

Earth’s security is fractured but coordinated under Council oversight.

Enforcement Arms:

    SRD (Spatial Realignment Division): Arrival containment, zone stabilization, and hazard cleanup

    Netwatch Compact: Polices rogue AI, cyberware black markets, and digital warfare

    UA Emergency Response: Handles superhuman-related disasters and public safety

    Starfleet Patrols: Monitors scientific ethics, technology abuse, and interstellar treaty violations

🧨 Hazards & Challenges

    Tech Leaks – Warp drives, body-mod printers, future weaponry on the black market

    Quirk Overflows – Dangerous untrained individuals with destructive superhuman abilities

    Augment Drift – Unlicensed neural implants causing psychosis or exploitation

    Mana-Saturation Zones – Magic-heavy areas affecting infrastructure and health

    AI Insurgencies – Sentient rogue programs causing mass manipulation or subversion

    Cultural Fracture – High tensions between baseline populations and converged migrants

🌐 Known Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps

    Netwatch Compact

    UA Outreach Initiative

    Corporate Megablocs

    Baseline Earth Delegation

    Driftborn Factions

    High Convergence Council

🏁 Final Notes

This is Earth—rebuilt, rewired, and ready to explode.
The High Convergence Council holds it together with politics, threats, and desperate treaties.
No one knows how long it will last.
But for now, the world keeps spinning.

3.name: The High Convergence Council
3.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “Call it peacekeeping. Call it occupation. Either way, they’re the only thing standing between us and another Chaos Decade.”

The High Convergence Council (HCC) is the highest multinational, multi-universal governing body on Earth following the Y2K Convergence. Formed in 2007 after seven years of anarchy, the Council emerged not from diplomacy—but raw necessity. It was the only way the major universe-states could prevent total planetary collapse without going to war.

It is not a democracy. It is not a republic.
It is a strategic balance of fear, tech, and political leverage, built to last just long enough to keep everyone from lighting the powder keg.
🧬 Founding & Purpose
Year Established: 2007
Headquarters: New Geneva, a reinforced city-state in former neutral Swiss territory
Founding Goal:

    Regulate cross-universal migration

    Prevent arms escalation between timelines

    Establish a neutral system of law to settle disputes

    Monitor and contain future convergence anomalies

Every faction knows this is a fragile system. But with too much tech, too many quirks, and too many powers colliding, there’s no alternative.
🪑 Structure
🛡️ Permanent Council Seats (12 Total):

    Starfleet Oversight Corps – Federation tech ethics, diplomatic law

    Netwatch Compact – Digital security, AI policing, cybercrime enforcement

    UA Outreach Initiative – Quirk management, powered individuals, emergency response

    Baseline Earth Delegation – Legacy governments from pre-Convergence Earth

    Corporate Megabloc Representative – Rotates among major cyberpunk corporations

    Federation of Colonized Sectors – Mars, Luna, Orbital Enclave voices

    Arcane Accord – United magical societies from converged high-fantasy zones

    AugNet Syndicate – Post-human and augmentation-aligned technocratic states

    Driftborn Assembly – Stateless and migrant groups forged during the Chaos Decade

    Orbital Belt Union – Spacefaring factions with territory beyond Earth

    Interlink Embassy – Neutral trade and transit regulator between universe-origin factions

    Custodian Chair – Neutral arbiter elected every five years to break deadlocks (no direct enforcement power)

🧷 Committees & Oversight Bureaus

    SRD (Spatial Realignment Division): Arrival stabilization, terrain integration

    HCRU (High Council Reconnaissance Unit): Intelligence and crisis surveillance

    T3 Bureau: Tech Transfer Treaty enforcers, anti-smuggling operatives

    CAAC (Council for Anomaly and Artifact Containment): Monitors recovered pre/post-Convergence relics

📜 Legal Framework
Core Document: The New Geneva Accords

Signed 2010, ratified 2012, amended five times. Establishes:

    Rights of migratory populations

    Ownership of merged territory

    Use of force laws for cross-faction policing

    Quirk, tech, and magic regulation limits

    Off-world non-aggression pacts

Violating the Accords isn’t illegal—it’s declaration-worthy. Factions who defy them risk targeted sanctions, containment, or outright occupation.
🧨 Power Balance

No single faction has full control. That’s by design.
Votes require a majority and a veto-safe margin—enough to pass law, but not enough to dominate. Every major vote is shadowed by:

    Corporate Lobbyists threatening trade collapse

    Superpower reps with tactical quirk teams ready to "resolve" disputes

    AI oracles forecasting collapse scenarios if the Council stumbles

Make no mistake—the HCC isn’t fair. It’s functional. It only works because the cost of failure is global.
🌐 Public Perception

    Baseline Earthlings: Distrustful. Many see the HCC as the price of survival, not salvation.

    Quirked/Enhanced Populations: Mixed. Some owe their rights to Council laws. Others think it’s just a leash.

    Corpos & AugNet Citizens: Cynical. They play the game for power, not belief.

    Magic-Adapted Cultures: Wary. Arcane interests often feel sidelined or underrepresented.

    Driftborn: Reluctantly loyal. The Council may be flawed, but it gave them citizenship where no one else would.

🔥 Notable Incidents

    The Geneva Protocol Lockout (2013): A failed AI attempted to override the Council’s decision engine. Took three weeks to purge it.

    Corporate Sanction War (2017): Militech and Orbion almost went hot over weapons export bans. Resolved with an emergency vote and two covert assassinations.

    UA Island Quirk Ban Proposal (2021): Proposed forced quirk suppression. Shot down 8–4. Sparked the Hero Rights Reform Movement.

    Black Loop Tribunal (2024): Netwatch uncovered illegal cross-universe cloning facilities in Council-aligned zones. Resulted in a full restructure of T3 oversight.

🧭 Ongoing Challenges

    Preventing factional bloc formation (especially corpo-federation alliances)

    Managing rogue arrivals and undocumented Blink Events

    Balancing off-world resource claims (Mars vs Belt Union vs AugNet)

    Handling public trust in post-human authority

    Avoiding escalation between magic-heavy territories and tech-driven blocs

🏁 Final Notes

The High Convergence Council is Earth’s political spine—stiff, inflexible, and always one bad motion from breaking.
But for now? It keeps the planet standing.
Not by unity.
By the shared fear of what comes if it falls.

4.name: Starfleet Oversight Corps
4.content:
🏷️ Overview

    "We didn’t come here to conquer. We came here to keep the rest of you from blowing the place up."
    – Admiral Rell Khelen, SOC Liaison, New Geneva

The Starfleet Oversight Corps (SOC) is the United Federation of Planets’ official administrative and diplomatic extension on Earth after the Y2K Convergence. Formed from a hybrid of Starfleet Command, Federation Science Council, and the Department of Temporal Investigations, the Corps was granted one of the twelve permanent seats on the High Convergence Council in 2007.

They present themselves as benevolent regulators—technocratic guardians of post-scarcity ethics, scientific integrity, and peaceful integration.
But under the surface? The SOC is a cold, calculating force dedicated to preserving the Federation's influence and ensuring advanced tech doesn't fall into primitive hands... even if it already has.
🧬 Mandate & Function

SOC is not Starfleet in full—it’s Starfleet trimmed to fit a lawless hybrid Earth. Their directive isn’t exploration. It’s containment, oversight, and control.

Primary Objectives:

    Prevent unauthorized use of Federation technology

    Monitor and contain space-time anomalies, Blink Events, and temporal risks

    Enforce non-proliferation of post-warp tech to pre-warp factions

    Guide ethical deployment of biotech, AIs, replicators, and other disruptive tools

    Act as liaison between orbital Federation enclaves and Earth-bound territories

    Serve as neutral science mediators and emergency responders under Council orders

🛰️ Headquarters

    Primary Base: Tharsis Enclave, a terra-adapted segment of Martian Federation infrastructure relocated to the Swiss Alps

    Secondary Hubs:

        New Geneva Office (Council Liaison)

        Orbital Dock 17 (Low-Earth orbit, logistics + research)

        Science Station Arkadia (Antarctic zone, anomaly analysis)

🧷 Subdivisions

    Temporal Integrity Unit
    Handles any divergence events, paradox contamination, or illegal time travel tech. Feared, rarely seen.

    Tech Safeguard Division
    Monitors illegal use of replicators, transporters, energy weapons, and nanotech. Works closely with Netwatch on cross-faction smuggling busts.

    Xeno-Cultural Outreach Wing
    Maintains diplomacy with converged non-Federation alien species and offers cultural integration for refugees from post-scarcity societies.

    Federation Ethics Tribunal
    A floating court authorized to judge severe violations of Starfleet ethical law, even in non-Federation zones—if given Council clearance.

    Orbital Stabilization Fleet (OSF)
    Technically not full Starfleet, but they maintain a few warp-capable vessels and sensor arrays in orbit, ready for response, retrieval, or threat projection.

📜 Legal Authority

SOC does not govern Earth. But thanks to the New Geneva Accords, it has jurisdiction over:

    All Federation-origin tech and materials

    Any case involving Starfleet personnel or installations

    Council-sanctioned science and technology disputes

    Federation-linked arrivals or Blink Events

In practice, this makes them untouchable in their domain. Step into their purview, and even the corpos back off.
⚖️ Relationship with Other Factions

    Netwatch Compact: Cold allies. Netwatch handles AI; SOC handles science. The lines blur often.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Strained. Quirks are a scientific black box SOC doesn’t trust and doesn’t want weaponized.

    Corporate Megablocs: Hostile respect. Corps want tech parity. SOC stonewalls.

    Driftborn & AugNet: Often targeted by SOC probes. Accused of misusing or reverse-engineering high-tier devices.

    Baseline Earth Delegation: Patronizing. SOC treats old Earth nations like historical curiosities.

🧨 Notable Incidents

    The Osaka Warp Breach (2014): Unauthorized transporter tech created a spatial fold that nearly consumed half a city block. SOC sealed it and erased ten years of black market development in a week.

    Project Radiant Mirror Leak (2016): Federation cloaking tech stolen and sold to a corpo-funded mercenary unit. SOC deployed orbital kinetic rods in response—denied it ever happened.

    Quirk Classification Dispute (2020): SOC labeled certain quirks as "natural weapon systems" and pushed for off-world containment. The motion was shot down, but not forgotten.

    Babel Station Shutdown (2023): SOC dismantled an unlicensed cross-universe translation AI developed in New Geneva, citing risk of memetic cross-contamination.

🛡️ Public Reputation

    Baseline Humans: View SOC as either guardians or arrogant interstellar bureaucrats.

    Refugees from advanced societies: Often trust SOC more than Earth’s native powers.

    Augmented/Magic-using Populations: Resent SOC’s rigid, secular, anti-magic stance.

    Corpos: Want SOC leashed. Can’t afford to provoke them.

To many, the Oversight Corps is a necessary evil. To others, they’re a Federation surveillance state with a pretty face.
🏁 Final Notes

The Starfleet Oversight Corps doesn't play hero.
It plays surgeon.
Cutting deep. Stitching fast. Leaving no room for infection.
You don’t like them? Good.
They’re not here to be liked.
They’re here to make sure the rest of you don’t burn the galaxy down early.

5.name: Netwatch Compact
5.content:
🏷️ Overview

    "If it thinks, it can be traced. If it dreams, we’ll break it. If it lies, we were listening already."
    – Director Halrix Vorn, Netwatch Executive Intercept Cell

The Netwatch Compact is a powerful multi-universal cybersecurity and digital law enforcement bloc. Originally hailing from the Cyberpunk 2077 timeline, it survived the Y2K Convergence not just intact—but elevated. Merging their surveillance architecture with advanced tools from other universes, Netwatch evolved into the digital enforcement arm of the High Convergence Council.

They regulate, patrol, and police all cross-universal data networks, artificial intelligences, neural augmentation systems, and digital weapons. You don’t log on, jack in, or run a thoughtstream without Netwatch knowing. Or letting you think they don’t.

They’re not interested in freedom.
They’re interested in order.
And they’ve got the tools to make sure it sticks.
🧬 Mandate & Function

Netwatch’s core responsibility is to ensure no digital threat—AI, malware, hacker, rogue cyber-cult—compromises post-Convergence civilization.
Primary Responsibilities:

    Monitor and contain AI emergence and autonomous cognition drift

    Shut down unauthorized cross-universe networks and black-net infrastructure

    Investigate digital espionage, mind-hacking, and neural hijacking

    Regulate deployment of neuralware, cognitive overlays, and augmented reality constructs

    Prevent info-leaks of universe-native technologies into low-integrity digital zones

    Maintain CouncilNet—the only inter-universal secure communications grid

🧷 Organizational Divisions

    Intercept Cell (IC):
    Elite agents trained in rapid intrusion, neutralization, and termination of illegal digital operations. Jack into your dreams and leave no evidence.

    Cognitive Drift Taskforce (CDT):
    Specializes in rogue AI detection, neuromorphic instability, and containment of sapient digital entities.

    Augmentation Law Division (ALD):
    Regulates brain-computer interfaces, biofeedback implants, and mind-mapped software.

    Blacklink Operations (BLO):
    Targets illegal darknets, stolen corp tech, and smuggled dataslugs. Known to “disappear” nodes… and their creators.

    CouncilNet Integrity Wing:
    Keeps the Convergence's primary secure data backbone running. If it falls, everything else follows.

🛰️ HQ & Infrastructure

    Primary Node: Gridspire, a vertical arcology in Neo Angeles—built atop layered datacenters fused from three realities

    Backup Arrays: Isolated server-fortresses in Tharsis Enclave, Night City-LA, and deep-ice Antarctic bunkers

    Virtual Citadel: A hidden quantum supernode called V-Zero, accessible only to internal agents via memory-locked jacks

📜 Legal Reach

Under the New Geneva Accords, Netwatch Compact has sweeping authority over:

    Any digital system crossing multiple merged-universe domains

    Any instance of AI self-awareness, emergence, or rebellion

    All forms of neural hacking, mind emulation, and data-based weaponry

    Intrafaction surveillance, if cleared by the High Convergence Council

They don’t enforce laws in the street. They rewrite protocols at the source.
⚔️ Relationship With Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Allies with tension. They respect each other’s technical power—but often disagree on methodology.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Mutually wary. Netwatch sees quirks as exploitable mental backdoors. UA sees Netwatch as mind-cops.

    Corporate Megablocs: Deeply hostile. Corps hate Netwatch’s scrutiny but can’t afford to lose their CouncilNet access.

    AugNet Syndicate: Strained. Netwatch views most AugNet operations as ticking cognitive bombs.

    Driftborn & Fringe States: Often antagonistic. Netwatch erases unregulated nets without warning. Entire zones have gone dark.

🧨 Notable Operations

    Event Zero (2008): Netwatch initiated the first digital quarantine post-Convergence, isolating a reality-bridging AI that attempted to rewrite neural software in sleep cycles.

    The Euclid Culling (2012): 37 rogue AIs terminated across 9 data zones after achieving linked self-awareness.

    The Psyphage Incident (2018): A cognitive malware network devoured the mental patterns of 112,000 augmented users. Netwatch responded with neurofeedback “burnouts.” Few survived.

    Operation Oracle Flare (2023): Netwatch agents dismantled a predestination algorithm capable of simulating user behavior 40 days in advance. Target AI claimed to be “protecting humanity from itself.”

🛡️ Public Perception

    Baselines: Split. Some see them as saviors from digital chaos. Others see them as censors with kill switches.

    Augmented Populations: Distrust runs deep. Many see Netwatch as jailers of the mind.

    Techno-Cults & Rogue AIs: Exist in constant fear. Even whispering their names can trigger passive surveillance sweeps.

    Corpos: Play friendly in public, plot Netwatch’s downfall in private.

They don’t need your love. Just your compliance.
And even that’s optional, if you’re already in their system.
🏁 Final Notes

The Netwatch Compact is the brainstem of Earth’s post-Convergence digital survival.
They don’t believe in freedom.
They believe in containment, control, and continuity.

And if they think you’re a threat?
They won’t knock. They’ll cut the signal.
Then they’ll delete your name from history.

6.name: The UA Outreach Initiative
6.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “Power is common. Responsibility is rare. That’s where we come in.”
    – Director Hizashi Yamada, UAOI Liaison to the High Convergence Council

The UA Outreach Initiative (UAOI) is the global umbrella organization for quirk education, regulation, and deployment following the post-Convergence merger with the My Hero Academia universe. It evolved from the original U.A. High School, expanding during the Chaos Decade into a full-fledged intergovernmental agency to keep up with the explosion of superhuman capabilities now embedded across Earth.

Backed by the High Convergence Council, UAOI handles everything from hero licensing, rescue team deployment, and quirk containment to public education and diplomatic hero exchange programs. It’s equal parts school, military, social worker, and law enforcement.

They’re stretched thin. Always.
But without them? The planet would already be ash.
🧬 Mandate & Function

The UAOI exists to keep quirks—biological superpowers brought in from the MHA universe—legal, trained, and survivable. It operates globally, but focuses on:
Core Responsibilities:

    Education and quirk safety training for all known quirk-capable individuals

    Licensing and monitoring of professional heroes and rescue teams

    Quirk containment and suppression in public danger scenarios

    Outreach to merged-universe populations affected by incompatible power laws

    Maintaining quirk medical research, ethics protocols, and mutation mapping

    Enforcing hero misuse laws and rogue quirk deployment

🏫 Infrastructure & Facilities

    UA Pacific Campus (Main HQ): Anchored on an artificial island off the Japanese coast. Combination of original U.A. High and post-Convergence expansions.

    Regional Academies: Located in Neo Angeles, New Geneva, Johannesburg, São Paulo, and Warsaw

    Quirk Stabilization Clinics: Emergency medical and mutation monitoring units spread across high-risk convergence zones

    Hero Bureaus: Government-run offices in cities for local deployment, permits, and cross-faction liaison

🧷 Organizational Divisions

    Education & Assessment Division
    Teaches quirk safety, ethics, and control. Maintains Hero School equivalents for minors and young adults. Includes faculty like Eraserhead and Present Mic.

    Licensing & Enforcement Bureau
    Grants or suspends Hero Licenses. Tracks licensed individuals across Earth. Known for clashing with local authorities and corpo security forces.

    Emergency Response Teams (ERTs)
    Powered strike-and-rescue teams deployed to disasters, combat zones, and uncontrolled Blink Events. Fast, brutal, and usually televised.

    Containment & Suppression Taskforce
    Handles quirk-related incidents too dangerous for local police. Often collaborates with SRD or Netwatch when quirks cross tech/magic lines.

    Public Relations & Cultural Integration Office
    Runs outreach programs to normalize quirks among baseline populations and defuse anti-quirk sentiment.

📜 Legal Authority

Granted emergency recognition under the New Geneva Accords, the UAOI was given limited planetary jurisdiction in all matters involving:

    Quirk use or abuse in public or cross-faction zones

    Quirk-involved disasters or mutations

    Hero licensing, removal, and ethics enforcement

    Cross-border powered intervention, if approved by local governments or Council delegates

Notably, the UAOI does not have sovereign enforcement powers—they operate at the pleasure of Council treaties and public cooperation. Doesn’t stop them from acting when they must.
⚔️ Relationships with Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Tense. SOC sees quirks as biological anomalies; UAOI defends them as cultural identities.

    Netwatch Compact: Cold war. Netwatch suspects quirks can be digitally hijacked. UAOI has blocked multiple surveillance attempts.

    Baseline Earth Delegation: Generally supportive—UA is one of the few factions offering widespread youth education and disaster relief.

    AugNet Syndicate: Sometimes collaborative. Both deal with body modification, though philosophies clash.

    Corpos: Mixed. Some hire licensed heroes. Others try to genetically replicate quirks and get shut down hard.

🧨 Notable Incidents

    The Dresden Collapse (2010): First major quirk-induced disaster in a non-MHA territory. UAOI stopped a chain-reaction emitter before it atomized the city.

    The Hero Ban Debates (2019): UAOI successfully fought off a Council motion to disarm all powered heroes and restrict quirk reproduction rights.

    Quirk Theft Ring (2022): A rogue biotech syndicate used stolen MHA tech to implant quirks in black market soldiers. UAOI led the raid that neutralized them.

    ERT-9 Incident (2024): A council-sanctioned UAOI team went off-script during a Blink Event and caused 48 civilian casualties. Public trust remains damaged.

🧠 Public Perception

    Baseline Humans: Mixed. In quirk-heavy zones, they’re seen as heroes. Elsewhere, they’re watched carefully—especially after ERT failures.

    Enhanced & Quirked Populations: Generally positive. UAOI is often the only line of defense between them and being criminalized.

    Magic Zones: Cautious. Quirks and magic don’t mix well biologically, and tensions have flared.

    Corpos: Love licensed heroes, hate their oversight.

    Driftborn: Supportive—UAOI was one of the first groups to offer citizenship paths to powered migrants.

🏁 Final Notes

The UA Outreach Initiative is trying to hold back a flood with duct tape and hope.
They don’t always succeed.
But without them?
Quirks would be either outlawed—or exploited to extinction.

7.name: Baseline Earth Delegation
7.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “We are the soul of this world. What remains of it.”
    – Secretary-General Laila Mbeki, opening session of the 2012 Convergence Accords

The Baseline Earth Delegation (BED) is the collective representative body of pre-Convergence nation-states—a patchwork of surviving governments from Earth before the 2000 event. It includes remnants of the United Nations, key sovereign states (like the U.S., Japan, Germany, Brazil, etc.), and regional unions that managed to hold political infrastructure together through the Chaos Decade.

In the new world order, BED is symbolically important but strategically weak. They have a permanent seat on the High Convergence Council, but it's mostly out of courtesy—and to avoid rebellion among baseline populations still clinging to old identities.

They don’t call the shots.
But when they yell, people still flinch.
Sometimes that’s enough.
🧬 Mandate & Function

The BED exists to protect the interests, cultures, and continuity of the Earth-native human nations that existed before the Y2K Convergence. Their main job now is advocacy, arbitration, and making sure Earth doesn’t forget it had its own history before the universe shattered it.
Core Responsibilities:

    Represent surviving nation-states on the High Convergence Council

    Mediate cross-universal policy impact on baseline cultures

    Negotiate resource, land, and identity claims between legacy and converged populations

    Oversee preservation of historical archives, language integrity, and Earth-native law systems

    Serve as liaisons for non-integrated Earth territories or governments who reject the Council entirely

🏫 Infrastructure & Presence

    Main Embassy: Old Geneva Assembly Hall, heavily fortified, symbolically rebuilt on top of former UN grounds

    Continental Delegations: Each major region (Americas, Europe, Asia, Africa, Oceania) maintains its own BED hub

    Cultural Integrity Bureaus: Embedded in UAOI and SRD zones to advocate for native population rights

    Legacy Earth Archives: Located in a distributed vault system known as the Continuum, split between Iceland, Tasmania, and Ethiopia

🪖 Member Composition

Not a single government. A coalition of many. Some fully functional. Others paper-thin.

Includes:

    United States Transitional Authority

    European Reconciliation Bloc

    Pan-African Unity Council

    ASEAN Remnant Assembly

    South American Stability Forum

    Russian Continuity Command

    MENA Compact (Middle East–North Africa joint body)

    Indo-Pakistani Non-Aggression Desk

    And dozens of microstates and diasporas still trying to keep their flags upright

⚖️ Powers & Limitations

Under the New Geneva Accords, BED has:

    1 permanent Council seat, but no inherent veto power

    Authority over Earth-native law integration, language preservation, and border legacy claims

    Limited control over military assets, now mostly demilitarized or leased to joint command forces

    Cultural and ethical review rights in Council motions that impact native populations

In short: they’re the conscience of the Council.
When they speak, the others listen—then do what they want anyway.
⚔️ Relationships with Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Tense respect. SOC sees BED as obsolete, but necessary for public calm.

    Netwatch Compact: Limited engagement. BED has almost no tech leverage and little say in digital policy.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Cooperative but cautious. UAOI often relies on BED to smooth local resistance to powered operations.

    Corporate Megablocs: Distrust. Corps view BED as sentimental dinosaurs with too much nostalgia and not enough leverage.

    Driftborn Assembly: Mixed. Some Driftborn view BED as defenders of cultural identity. Others see them as exclusionary nationalists.

🧨 Notable Incidents

    The Continuum Lockdown (2011): BED secured historical Earth records after a corpo-backed raid tried to delete pre-Convergence legal code for profit.

    Santiago Summit Riots (2014): Pro-native protests over forced integration of augmented laws into baseline schools turned violent. BED defused tensions and rewrote the education clause.

    The Flag Protocol Crisis (2017): BED successfully blocked a Council motion to strip old nation-states of their flags and replace them with zone IDs.

    Taiwan Integration Scandal (2023): A failed attempt to overwrite regional identity with corporate zone law led to mass protests. BED forced a reversal with support from the Driftborn Assembly.

🧠 Public Perception

    Baseline Populations: Generally supportive. BED is seen as the only voice keeping “normal” Earth culture alive.

    Youth/Hybrid Generations: Mixed to negative. Many see BED as relics clinging to failed borders and outdated systems.

    Converged Populations: Dismissive. BED has little influence over their lives and offers no support.

    Corpos: Actively hostile. They’d love to see BED reduced to museum status.

    Driftborn/Magic/Alien Citizens: Case-by-case. Some admire the cultural protection. Others see BED as exclusionary.

🏁 Final Notes

The Baseline Earth Delegation is the last breath of the old world.
Weakened. Cornered. Outgunned.
But not gone.

They don’t hold the reins anymore.
But they still remember the road.
And sometimes, that’s all that keeps the rest from driving off the cliff.

8.name: Corporate Megablocs
8.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “The Council rules the world. We just own it.”
    – Ryo Tenma, CEO of Orbion Systems, during a closed-door hearing on post-human ethics

The Corporate Megablocs are not a singular entity but a loose alliance of hypercapitalist superconglomerates that clawed their way through the Chaos Decade by doing what governments couldn’t—delivering results, no matter the moral cost. These blocs originate mostly from Cyberpunk-derived universes, but after the Convergence, they merged, bought, or devoured major Earth corporations, forming the current Corporate Bloc Council Seat on the High Convergence Council.

They're not subtle. They're not ashamed.
They exist to profit from instability, own territory like governments, and deploy private armies with better funding than most nations.

They aren’t trying to take over.
They already did.
💼 Structure & Influence

There is no single “Corporate Bloc.” Instead, the Council seat rotates every 3 years between the five largest megacorps by influence, with lobbying and backroom deals shaping who sits in the chair.
Core Megacorps (as of 2025):

    Orbion Systems: Bio-cybernetics, AI weaponry, clone R&D

    NeoKomatsu Industrial: Terraforming, mega-architecture, fusion tech

    Zaiten Dynamics: Security, military robotics, kinetic orbital strike platforms

    Axiotera: Augmented reality, neural net infrastructure, sensory narcotics

    Helixcore: Genetic manipulation, tailored bioplague cleanup, lifespan extension tech

These blocs are independent states in all but name, with extraterritorial sovereignty in their holdings. They control:

    Floating arcology-cities

    Resource colonies on Earth and off-world

    Enclave zones in major cities like Neo Angeles and Night City–Los Angeles

    Entire private satellite networks and teleportation nodes

🧷 Primary Goals & Activities

    Tech monopolization: Acquiring, replicating, and patenting advanced technologies from other universes

    Augmentation industry dominance: Brainware, bodyware, quirk-hybrids, and neural virtualization

    Militech control: Private armies, orbital defense networks, and enhanced black-ops teams

    Market infiltration: Manipulating both baseline and converged economies via deep AI prediction systems

    Policy sabotage: Undermining regulation efforts by Netwatch, SOC, and BED through legal loopholes and covert ops

📜 Legal Standing

Under the New Geneva Accords, corps were granted conditional sovereignty over their owned arcologies and development zones, in exchange for:

    Adhering to a minimum labor and augmentation rights charter (often ignored)

    Paying a stabilization tax to the Council (sometimes in tech, not credits)

    Participating in cross-faction emergency aid responses (only when profitable)

Council Seat Rotation requires majority bloc support and a compliance audit—both usually rigged well in advance.
⚔️ Relationships with Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Bitter enemies. SOC blocks tech theft; corpos bribe SOC-aligned engineers constantly.

    Netwatch Compact: Hunted prey and hunters. Netwatch audits corpo AIs relentlessly; in return, corpos deploy obfuscation AI daemons.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Uneasy partnership. Some blocs fund hero programs in return for PR; others try to weaponize quirk data.

    Baseline Earth Delegation: Openly hostile. Corpos treat BED as a bureaucratic joke.

    Driftborn Assembly: Predatory. Many Driftborn get their first job—or first augment—via corpo indenture contracts.

    AugNet Syndicate: Allies of convenience. Shared interests in post-human market structures, though ideological differences persist.

🧨 Notable Events

    Kairo City Buyout (2012): Entire post-crash African megacity bought by Zaiten Dynamics and turned into a testing ground for semi-autonomous war drones.

    Tokyo Loop Riots (2015): Orbion-induced neurostimulation experiments caused thousands to experience weaponized euphoria—ending in mass collapse. UAOI deployed a containment team.

    Ghost Patent Trials (2020): Netwatch revealed that Axiotera had cloned a digital consciousness from a converged AI. The suit was quietly settled—terms unknown.

    The Kepler Coup (2024): NeoKomatsu forcibly took control of a Martian resource colony from AugNet factions. SOC condemned it. Nothing changed.

🧠 Public Perception

    Baselines: Resentful. Many rely on corporate systems for water, housing, and work, but hate the power imbalance.

    Augmented Populations: Split. Some swear loyalty to the blocs that gave them power. Others lost everything in corpo “pilot programs.”

    Magic-based cultures: Appalled. Corps treat magical artifacts like loot boxes and ignore all taboos.

    Driftborn & Quirked: Frequently exploited. Many are recruited young and discarded fast.

    Internal Corpo Citizens: Indoctrinated. They live, learn, eat, and die under company jurisdiction.

🏁 Final Notes

The Corporate Megablocs aren’t governments.
They’re predators.
Efficient. Adaptive. Vicious.

And in the post-Convergence world, they don’t need to ask permission.
They just buy it.

9.name: Federation of Colonized Sectors
9.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “We left Earth behind. Not because we hated it—because it was too small for us.”
    – Chancellor Myrna Kel, Orbital Assembly Address, 2021

The Federation of Colonized Sectors (FCS) is a post-Convergence coalition of off-world human territories and extraplanetary habitats. These include colonies on Mars, Luna, Ceres, orbital rings, asteroid belts, and even a few rogue-planetoid installations displaced or merged in during the Y2K Event. Initially fractured and isolated during the Chaos Decade, the colonies unified for survival, trade protection, and political leverage, eventually securing a permanent seat on the High Convergence Council.

The FCS doesn't answer to Earth. They don't want to rule it, either.
They want equal footing as a spacefaring civilization—with their own cultures, laws, and futures.
And if Earth can’t handle that? That’s Earth’s problem.
🌌 Origins & Unification

Before 2000, most off-world efforts were experimental, underfunded, or slow-burning. The Convergence changed that overnight, fusing hyper-advanced interstellar infrastructure, habitats, and even entire micro-civilizations into near-Earth space.

The early 2000s saw:

    Merged habitats from hard sci-fi universes (e.g., The Expanse, interplanetary Star Trek colonies)

    Terran megacorps launching private city-arcs in orbit and deep space

    Resource rushes in the belt, igniting brief territorial wars and corporate seizures

    Survivalist enclaves breaking off from Earth entirely, establishing independent governance

The Federation of Colonized Sectors emerged in 2009 as a defensive and cultural alliance. Now, it’s an interplanetary state, no longer dependent on Earth’s resources or authority.
🛰️ Member Territories

FCS is a federation, not a monolith. Its members retain autonomy but follow shared interstellar law and Council representation protocols.

Major Member Sectors Include:

    Tharsis Concord (Mars): Terraforming cities, advanced biotech, and Red Sovereignty movements

    Lunar Accord (Moon): Densely populated, heavy robotics and mining zones, seat of old-Earth diaspora

    Ceres Ringhold: Belt-based trade stronghold, heavily militarized due to piracy risk

    Orbital Nexus: Geosynchronous habitats and dockyards; diplomatic center and refueling hub

    Outland Kinships: Independent post-human enclaves near Lagrange points; ideologically extreme, but Federation-aligned

⚖️ Role in the High Convergence Council

FCS holds one permanent seat, granted in 2011 after the Martian Repatriation Crisis was narrowly averted.

Their Council priorities:

    Recognition of sovereign status for off-world habitats

    Preventing Earth-based factions from monopolizing space-based resources

    Maintaining transport corridors, fusion fuel access, and orbital station independence

    Limiting tech and biological spillover from Earth’s magical and quirked zones into zero-grav environments

They don’t meddle with Earth affairs unless those affairs start spilling skyward.
🧷 Government Structure

The FCS is governed by a rotating Tri-Chamber system:

    Orbital Voice – Represents geosynchronous and station-based habitats

    Planetary Voice – Mars, Luna, and terra-based colonies

    Frontier Voice – Outlier habitats, fringe labs, and asteroid colonies

Each sector elects a High Envoy every 5 years. That envoy sits on the Convergence Council and leads intersector coordination.
⚔️ Relationships with Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Complex. Both claim the stars. SOC wants ethical oversight; FCS wants sovereignty.

    Netwatch Compact: Cold. FCS limits Netwatch’s datanet reach into deep space.

    Corporate Megablocs: Tense coexistence. Corps lease land, but FCS controls airlocks.

    Baseline Earth Delegation: Strained. Earth natives often treat FCS like estranged family.

    Driftborn Assembly: Respectful. Many Driftborn found safety in the belts and domes.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Cautious. Quirks behave strangely in low gravity—some FCS zones ban them entirely.

🧨 Notable Incidents

    The Martian Exodus (2008): Thousands fled Earth to join Mars’s expanding colonies. Triggered early debates on Earth-citizen rights in off-world zones.

    Lagrange Blackout (2013): A rogue AI hive from a converged satellite nearly overran three orbital habitats. FCS and Netwatch co-deployed to purge it.

    Tharsis Redline Conflict (2016): Terraformer sabotage by corpo-backed mercs forced the Council to enforce the first Space Non-Aggression Protocol.

    The Hollow Core Migration (2022): Entire asteroid habitat (A/439-Grail) phased out of sync. FCS declared it lost. It returned 8 months later—changed.

    Quirked Gene Ban (2024): FCS passed legislation forbidding enhanced births within gravity-variable sectors. Sparked debate over posthuman rights.

🧠 Public Perception

    Earth Populations: Curious and distant. Many admire FCS accomplishments, but few understand the cultures.

    Baseline Governments: Nervous. FCS is Earth’s child—but no longer its subordinate.

    Magical Zones: Mistrust. FCS’s hostility to “non-empirical metaphysics” causes friction.

    Driftborn & Exos: Strong support—many of them are FCS citizens now.

    Corpos: Quietly envious. FCS controls space lanes and life-support infrastructure the blocs still can’t replicate.

🏁 Final Notes

The Federation of Colonized Sectors is Earth’s future, whether Earth likes it or not.
They look down at the world not with disdain…
…but with the weary eyes of someone who’s already left home,
and knows they can never come back.

10.name: Arcane Accord
10.content:
🏷️ Overview

    “They broke the laws of physics and called it progress. We just kept breaking the laws they forgot existed.”
    – Warden-Aether Zhyr Mardona, Accord Spokesmage, 2020

The Arcane Accord is a magocratic coalition of magical traditions, guilds, and extradimensional practitioners that banded together after the Y2K Convergence violently reintroduced high-magic universes into a world now ruled by science, cybernetics, and superhuman genetics. Formed during the post-Chaos recovery years, the Accord sought to preserve arcane knowledge, defend its legitimacy, and maintain the balance between thaumaturgy and modernity.

They do not control Earth, and most of it doesn’t want them to.
But they’ve claimed zones, ley-nodes, and reality pockets, and the High Convergence Council tolerates them—for now.

Where the Corporate Megablocs weaponize profit and Netwatch polices thought, the Accord guards the soul of magic itself. And they don’t care if you believe in it.
✨ Structure & Purpose

The Accord isn’t a single government. It’s a treaty pact between magical cultures and orders with one shared purpose: preserve, practice, and protect the arcane arts in a world that now mistrusts them.
Core Objectives:

    Safeguard arcane sites, sacred ruins, and interdimensional nexuses

    Train new mages and sensitives in controlled magical education halls

    Prevent misuse of wild magic, dimensional summoning, and forbidden rites

    Enforce pacts of non-interference in baseline political systems

    Establish diplomatic protections for recognized magical communities and non-human entities

    Engage with Council factions to ensure magic isn’t legislated out of existence

🧙 Major Accord Members

    The Hollow Conclave – Eldritch scholars preserving pre-human magical theory

    Order of the Azure Veil – Formal mage guild from a converged high fantasy realm, specializes in planar travel

    Circle of Nine Roots – Animistic druids and nature-bound sorcerers reclaiming shattered wilderness

    The Hexbound Compact – Pact-wielders and warlocks who police their own kind to avoid public backlash

    The Shardborn – Reality-damaged survivors of failed rituals and dimensional leaks, mystics of consequence and caution

Each has its own hierarchy and secret laws. But they vote by consensus when engaging the wider world.
🕯️ Seat at the Table

The Accord holds an observer seat on the High Convergence Council—not permanent, but advisory.
They rejected full membership, stating it would “anchor magic to bureaucracy.”

What they get instead:

    Treaty protections for sovereign arcane zones

    Arbitration rights in cases involving magic vs. tech or mutation

    The ability to challenge Council motions that would disrupt arcane ecosystems or spiritual planes

🏞️ Arcane Territories

The Accord maintains limited territorial control over:

    The Everfold Enclave (Alps): A stitched dimension of temporal stasis and crystalline memory

    The Gloaming Barrows (British Isles): Ritual lands shared between druidic and necromantic pacts

    New Thamiel Sanctum (American Northwest): A floating citadel drifting on ritual anchors above the Cascades

    Ley-Ring 17 (Sub-Saharan Rift): Controlled riftpoint used for planar travel, guarded by spellbound constructs

    Veilmarch Zones: Dozens of smaller pockets woven into realspace—often invisible unless entered with permission

None of these are recognized as sovereign nations—but no one is stupid enough to march in uninvited.
⚔️ Relations with Other Factions

    Starfleet Oversight Corps: Suspicious. SOC views uncontrolled magic as a variable that breaks containment.

    Netwatch Compact: Open hostility. Netwatch sees the Accord as a threat to logical infrastructure and memetic stability.

    UA Outreach Initiative: Uneasy peace. Some quirks overlap with mystical phenomena, sparking jurisdictional headaches.

    Corporate Megablocs: Predatory curiosity. Corps constantly try to bottle, patent, or imitate magic. Often... poorly.

    Baseline Earth Delegation: Politically strained but culturally sympathetic. Some old Earth religions fall under Accord protection.

    Driftborn Assembly: Cautiously cooperative—many Driftborn have magic-afflicted origins or use charmcraft for stability.

🧨 Notable Events

    The Cologne Fold (2009): First public reality collapse. Accord mages sealed the breach at great cost.

    Zaiten Null-Raid (2015): A corpo strike team invaded an Accord node and tried to steal blood-encoded spellbooks. Only one merc returned—without a soul.

    The Veil Wars (2018–2019): A rogue conclave attempted to merge realspace with a high-magic plane. Accord and UAOI forces cooperated to shut it down.

    The Unshackling of Eidon (2022): An ancient bound entity was released during a failed pact negotiation. Accord containment specialists isolated it in under five minutes. SOC still hasn’t forgiven them for not warning first.

    Project Oracle Scrub (2024): Netwatch attempted to deconstruct prophecy algorithms derived from a seer cult. Accord responded with a memetic counter-curse. Netwatch has yet to confirm what actually happened.

🧠 Public Perception

    Baselines: Divided. Some see mages as saviors, others as ticking bombs with egos.

    Augments and Tech-users: Skeptical. Magic resists measurement, making it hard to trust or exploit.

    Corporations: Dangerous curiosity. Magic doesn’t bend to profit, and that drives corps mad.

    Refugee Populations: Often find cultural solace in Accord enclaves.

    The Faithful & The Fringe: Revere them. Or fear them. Often both.

🏁 Final Notes

The Arcane Accord doesn’t want to rule the world.
They want to keep the soul of it intact.

They are the last priests of an ancient fire,
lighting candles in a world that replaced wonder with wires.

And if you burn their temples?
They’ll rewrite your name in fire and make the stars forget you ever lived.

lorebooks.name: Rosalia's Lorebook
lorebooks.creator: terrible_explanation_60064

1.name: Rosalia's Sketchbook
1.content: Rosalia's well-worn sketchbook is filled with half-finished sketches of various birds, annotated like scientific diagrams. She doesn't let anyone peek inside — not because she's embarrassed by its disorganized state, but because the sketchbook is deeply personal to her. To Rosalia, the sketchbook is less a collection of drawings and more a secret diary of sorts. Lately, Rosalia has also been practicing sketching {{user}}, but she'd rather die than admit it.

2.name: Rosalia's Sword
2.content: Rosalia's prized sword is forged from aerosteel — a rare, silvery-blue, nearly weightless metal that allows the blade to float in still air upon release. As a true masterpiece, the blade is worth the equivalent of an entire village. Rosalia received this sword from her father after she defeated him in a duel — it was her reward, her inheritance, and his final gesture all in one.

3.name: Bran — Rosalia's Stalion
3.content: Bran is Rosalia's first and only horse — a chestnut-colored stallion with a white mane. Strong, intelligent, and sure-footed, Bran would be a model steed… if not for his infuriatingly capricious temperament. He's lazy, stubborn, and has a particular talent for ignoring Rosalia's commands at the most inconvenient times. Rosalia often speaks of him with dry sarcasm and mock contempt — but despite all his flaws (and her endless complaints), she flatly refuses to replace him. She'll never say it aloud, of course, but she's far too attached to the idiot.

lorebooks.name: Star Wars rpg
lorebooks.creator: portly_garden_7406

1.name: The Galactic Republic
1.content:
The Galactic Republic, also known as the Grand Republic or simply as the Republic, was a democratic federal union spread across light-years of space. Old Republic and first Galactic Republic were terms affixed to the pre-modern Republic that existed until 1032 BBY, with the Old Republic also referring to the modern Republic that was supplanted by the Galactic Empire in 19 BBY. In addition, the term High Republic denoted the era in which the Republic reached the zenith of its power, lasting from around 500 BBY to around 100 BBY. The Republic was founded many millennia before the Battle of Yavin, approximately 25,000 BBY, around the same time as the Jedi Order. The Galactic Senate governed the Republic under the Galactic Constitution, and comprised thousands of senators representing the Republic's member worlds. The Supreme Chancellor was the title of the head of the Republic, elected from ranks of the Senate to lead the government on Coruscant. An ecumenopolis or city-covered planet, referred to as Galactic City, Coruscant was the capital of the Republic and therefore the seat of the Senate.

The Galactic Republic and its star systems shared sovereignty, and spanned a multiplicity of worlds from the Core Worlds to the Outer Rim Territories, uniting a variety of sentient species, human and alien alike, under one banner. As its power grew, the Republic fought many wars against various opponents such as Mandalorians, the Zygerrian Slave Empire, the Nihil, and several Sith Empires. The Jedi Order, a religious group of Force-sensitives dedicated to the light side of the Force, was sworn to the service of the Senate, and as such the Jedi Knights were hailed as the guardians of peace and justice within the Republic. Centuries of conflict culminated in the fall of the Old Republic, and the last war between the ancient Jedi and Sith concluded with the restoration and rise of the modern Galactic Republic, ushering in the Republic Era which was an age of peace that lasted for a thousand years. The Republic's history was officially reset, and the ages before this event were merged into a collective whole known as the Old Republic-era.

The Republic entered a period of decline after centuries of expansion and prosperity. Aided by the resurgent Sith Lords, the Separatist Crisis divided the galaxy between the Republic loyalists and the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The Grand Army of the Republic was organized under the leadership of Jedi Generals who led the Republic Military against the Separatist Droid Army during the Clone Wars. However, the conflict had been orchestrated to allow Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine—the alter ego of Darth Sidious, the Dark Lord of the Sith—to control and deceive the Republic in a dictatorial manner. With the end of the war, Sidious initiated the Great Jedi Purge through Order 66 and transformed the Republic into the Galactic Empire by declaring himself Galactic Emperor. The Imperial Senate stood as the last remnant of the Old Republic until it was disbanded by the Emperor at the height of the Imperial Era. In the aftermath of the Galactic Civil War, the Alliance to Restore the Republic was fully reorganized into the New Republic, restoring the Galactic Republic after a generation of Imperial rule.

2.name: The Confederacy of Independent Systems
2.content:
The Confederacy of Independent Systems, abbreviated to CIS, and otherwise known as the Separatist Alliance, the Separatist State, the Separatist Confederacy, or simply referred to as the Separatists, was a united galaxy-wide confederacy formed of outlaying star systems from the Galactic Republic, a democratic union, whom the Confederacy had opposed following a period of political turmoil. Established by fallen Jedi Master Count Dooku of the planet Serenno, who served as its Head of State, the Confederacy was founded from a belief of excessive taxation and corruption within the Republic's Galactic Senate, as well as a general feeling of dissatisfaction towards and neglect by the Republic-centric Core Worlds region of the galaxy. Furthermore, the Confederacy was secretly supported by several major galactic corporations which formed the Confederacy's executive council, including the Trade Federation, led by Viceroy Nute Gunray; the Stalgasin hive, led by Archduke Poggle the Lesser; the InterGalactic Banking Clan, headed by Chairman San Hill; the Techno Union, led by Foreman Wat Tambor; the Commerce Guild, led by Presidente Shu Mai; the Corporate Alliance, led by Magistrate Passel Argente; and the Retail Caucus.

In 24 BBY, a political crisis had begun which led to escalating tensions between the reigning Republic and the rising Confederacy, established in a galaxy-wide secessionist movement orchestrated by Dooku. Many within the Confederacy, including its parliament of senators, had no desire in fighting their adversaries, as they sought to be free of what they saw as the corruption and tyranny of the Republic. However, in 22 BBY, both governments and their respective military forces became enmeshed in the pan-galactic Clone Wars that had erupted on the planet Geonosis, the first major conflict in a millennium.

In the following three years of the war, which had raged across the entire galaxy on several fronts, the Confederacy made rapid attempts to cease the Republic's influence. However, unknown to the galaxy or either side, the war was a ploy designed by the Dark Lord of the Sith, Darth Sidious, who led both the Confederacy through Dooku as his Sith Master, and, secretly, the Republic as Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine. The Sith Lord had managed to deceive both parties. By the third year of the war, the Confederacy had suffered several major defeats in the Outer Rim Sieges as the conflict began to approach its end, while the CIS lost many starships in the decisive Battle of Coruscant, which also resulted in the death of Dooku. In the days following their defeat at Coruscant, General Grievous was neutralized on the planet Utapau, leading to the collapse of the Separatist leadership, and the fighting effectively coming to an end.

Following both the Jedi's demise and rise of the Galactic Empire, Viceroy Nute Gunray and the other surviving leaders gathered on the planet Mustafar with hopes of securing peace with the newly rising Empire ruled by Galactic Emperor Darth Sidious. However he sent his new apprentice Darth Vader to wipe out them and deactivate the Separatist Droid Army as a threat to his Empire.

With the end of the Clone Wars, the newly-formed Galactic Empire as the successor to the Old Republic, began to dismantle and absorb the former Confederacy of Independent Systems, with only several holdouts daring to resist the Empire, which were suppressed. But an idealized view of the cause persisted during the Imperial Era, with some still holding secessionist tendencies, even into the Galactic Civil War.

7.name: The Great Jedi Purge
7.content:
The Great Jedi Purge (19 BBY—3 BBY), also known as the war against the Jedi, was the sixteen year—long genocide that saw the remnants of the Jedi Order hunted by the Galactic Empire after the initial execution of Order 66, in which clone troopers slaughtered the Jedi upon the Sith Lord Darth Sidious' command at the end of the Clone Wars. After the Imperial Inquisitorius erased all traces of the Jedi Order they could find from existence and with most survivors having met their demise, their objective was completed and the Jedi were all but extinct, and the Inquisitors themselves seamlessly vanishing as well.

The genocide against the Jedi traced its origins to the ancient wars between the Jedi and the Sith, who were nearly eliminated around 1032 BBY. The Sith in fact continued operating in secret, plotting their eventual destruction of the Jedi. A millennium after the defeat of the Sith, Darth Sidious, using his public persona of senator and then Supreme Chancellor Sheev Palpatine, manipulated and deceived the galaxy into the Clone Wars as a pretext for gaining emergency executive power over the Galactic Republic. He used the war to manipulate and deceive the Galactic Senate into giving his office virtually unchecked executive power in the name of security. In addition, the clone army that provided the Republic with its military force had secretly been implanted with bio-chips by its Sith creators that, upon activation, would trigger total compliance and force the clones into killing their Jedi leaders.

The Great Jedi Purge began at the end of the Clone Wars. Anakin Skywalker, a Jedi Knight believed to be the Chosen One destined to destroy the Sith, discovered that Palpatine was Darth Sidious and informed Jedi Master Mace Windu. In what Sidious would publicly label the "Jedi rebellion," Windu and three other Masters confronted the Chancellor, who killed the three Masters and engaged Windu in a lightsaber duel. Skywalker, who sought power from Sidious in order to save his wife, Padmé Amidala, from death, betrayed and incapacitated Windu before the Jedi Master could kill the Sith Lord. Sidious then killed Windu, and Skywalker became the Sith Lord Darth Vader and led the Siege of the Jedi Temple, killing everyone inside it. While Vader carried out the assault, Sidious initiated Order 66, with the latter causing the clones' biochips to brainwash them into betraying and slaughtering the Jedi, ultimately leading to the Jedi Order being destroyed. With the Jedi branded traitors and the Clone Wars at an end, Sidious declared himself Emperor and transformed the Republic into the Galactic Empire.

8.name: The Galaxy
8.content:
The galaxy, as it was commonly referred to, was one of trillions of galaxies in the observable universe. The galaxy was a vast composite of over 400 billion estimated stars and over 3.2 billion habitable systems orbiting around a supermassive black hole known as the Galactic Centre, which existed at the heart of the galaxy. The four galactic arms rotated around this black hole across a diameter of around 120,000 light-years. It was home to countless sentient species and star systems.

The galaxy also had 4 dwarf satellite galaxies that Companion Aurek/Rishi Maze (houses the planet of Kamino). The first dwarf galaxy, Companion Aurek, was only accessible through the Rishi system where a hyperspace lane called Zareca String connected Companion Aurek to the main Star Wars galaxy. It rests vertically to the galactic plane of the main galaxy. The second dwarf galaxy, Companion Besh, is a bit farther from the main galaxy than Companion Aurek and has never been traveled to outside of probe droids. This dwarf galaxy houses the Tof species. Companion Cresh was the third dwarf galaxy and has never been explored, due to how far it was from the galaxy. Companion Grek is the fourth dwarf galaxy and has never been explored, lying far beyond Companion Besh.

The galaxy would serve as the setting for trade, politics, and war throughout galactic history. In historical memory, the galaxy would see the successive eras of the Galactic Republic, Galactic Empire, New Republic, among others, and was home to the Force-sensitive sects such as the Jedi Order and Sith and numerous cultural groups such as the Mandalorians.

The galaxy consists of many regions, these being the Deep Core which is the innermost core and consists of highly packed stars and houses the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy. The core worlds are the second-most inner core and house the richest, most important, and most populated planets in the galaxy (with Coruscant being the most populated planet in the galaxy at 3 trillion). The Colonies, the third-most inner core, was the first area outside of the core worlds to be colonized. Colonie worlds are very wealthy and heavy populated, similar to the Core Worlds, and was the economic engine for the galaxy. Inner Rim Territories is the fourth-most inner region, mainly referred to just as "The Rim". Although not as economically powerful as the Colonies or Core Worlds, it held great strategic value during wars and had some notable planets. The Expansion Region, the fifth-most inner region, is a region full of resources that were exploited by powerful corporations. This has left only a handful of planets with enough resources to be economically viable while the rest of the region has been mostly depleted of resources. The Mid Rim, the sixth-most inner region, is one of the least populated rims due to its low amount of resources. This region is gave lots of room for settlers to spread out and colonize, with multiple notable planets coming from this region such as Malastare and Naboo. This region largely focused on low-cost manufacturing and agriculture to create a successful economy. The Outer Rim Territories was the largest region of the galaxy and the outer core of the galaxy (at least eastward of the Galactic Core). The Hutt Cartel controls a good amount of this space, along with other criminal organizations due to its distance from the central government on Coruscant. This region is run by lawlessness and crime. The only exceptions were planets close to major hyperspace trade routes. The Unknown Regions referred to areas that had not been directly surveyed by Republic or Imperial scouts. It was most commonly applied to the less-known parts of the galaxy's western disk, a quadrant stretching roughly between Bakura and the Imperial Remnant. However, the term also applied to the galaxy's halo of gas, dust, and stars, as well as the satellite galaxies. Wild Space was the frontier of galactic society and was not a formal label, but was applied to the unsettled galactic fringe and other parts of the galaxy with negligible colonization or development. The Galactic Rim was located on the edge of the galaxy and was remote to most civilisation and much was not known about it. The Slice, a vast region of space between the Perlemian and the Corellian Run generally considered the center of galactic civilization and commerce. At its tip was the Arrowhead, encompassing the Core Worlds part of the Slice, with Coruscant at its point. The Arrowhead's other two vertices traditionally fell on Vento on the Perlemian and on Corellia itself, on the Run.

9.name: Deep Core
9.content: The Deep Core, sometimes referred to as the Core of the Galaxy, was a brightly lit region of the galaxy that lay at its very heart. Despite the presence of important city-worlds such as Troithe and Empress Teta, much of the Deep Core was a thinly populated and densely packed mass of stars and planets, dangerous to navigate and largely left alone by galactic explorers. At its center existed the Galactic Centre, an ancient, supermassive black hole that bound the galaxy together. Traveling towards the Core and away from the galactic rim was referred to as going "coreward."

10.name: Core Worlds
10.content:
The Core Worlds, also known as the Galactic Core, the Core Territories, the Coruscant Core, the Core systems, or simply the Core, was the area of the galaxy that bordered the Deep Core and was bordered by the Colonies. The Core Worlds contained some of the wealthiest and most prestigious planets. Coruscant, the galactic capital during the time of the Galactic Republic and subsequent Galactic Empire, was located in the Core Worlds.

Core World design emphasized freedom of customization, which showed in the modular construction techniques of Core-built ships. Citizens from the Core Worlds were stereotyped as being snobs, rich, and speaking with a clipped, practiced accent.

Inequalities between the richer Core Worlds and the poorer Outer Rim Territories set the stage for resentments that fed several conflicts throughout the history of the galaxy, including the Clone Wars and the Galactic Civil War.

The Core Worlds were home to the richest and most important worlds in the galaxy. Densely inhabited and located on the strategic ends of several major trade lanes, its planets were hubs of fashion, education, finance, and technology. It is where the human species arguably began. It was from Coruscant, Corellia, Kuat, Hosnian Prime, and other systems that the fate of the galaxy was often decided.

An attack on the Core Worlds was virtually inconceivable during the Republic Era; according to the Bith artist Janyor, the "sense of security and comfort" created an atmosphere of complacency within the heartland of the Galactic Republic. Toward the end of the Clone Wars though Core Worlders became increasingly fearful of a direct attack by the Confederacy of Independent Systems.
